Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Cognition and signaling in songbirds
Award.AbstractNarration: This research will examine associations between communication signals and cognitive ability in two species of songbirds. Song in these species is learned: males memorize external models early in life, and then use these memories to shape their own production when they begin to sing many months later. Because song development involves learning and memory, it is logical to hypothesize an association between song and other aspects of cognition. To test that hypothesis, cognitive ability will be measured in a series of laboratory tasks, for example a novel motor task, in which subjects learn to remove lids from the wells of a foraging grid to obtain food, a color association task, in which subjects learn to associate food with lids of a particular color, and a spatial task, in which subjects learn that food can be found only in certain locations. These cognitive measures will then be related to aspects of song that are the outcome of learning, such as the accuracy with which song models are copied during development and the frequency of sharing of song types with others in the local population. Vocal learning in songbirds shows a series of striking parallels with speech development in humans, and therefore results on the tie between vocal development and cognition in songbirds will have implications for the relationship between cognition and speech in humans. Results from the study will be disseminated not only in scientific outlets but also in workshops for high school biology teachers designed to demonstrate how the study of animal behavior can be used to teach the scientific method.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the relationships in songbirds between different aspects of cognitive performance, with special focus on song learning ability. In humans, all measures of cognitive performance tend to be positively associated, meaning that individuals that do well on one cognitive test tend to do well on all others. Such results have led to the somewhat controversial idea that humans possess a general intelligence factor, or g. A few other mammals, such as mice and rats, show similar evidence of a general intelligence factor, but whether this phenomenon is widespread among animals is not known. Songbirds are of special interest in this regard, because like humans, and unlike rats and mice, songbirds exhibit vocal learning, meaning that they learn the details of their vocalizations by listening to and copying others. Songbirds therefore can be assessed for vocal learning abilities that are analogous to verbal fluency skills in humans, and that have no analog in most non-human mammals. If song learning ability does correlate with other aspects of cognitive performance, then song could be used by birds to assess individual intelligence.

 

We studied two species of songbirds, swamp sparrows and song sparrows. We assessed vocal learning ability in swamp sparrows from the “typicality” of the songs of adult males recorded in nature. The songs of a population of swamp sparrows form clusters in a multi-dimensional acoustic space defined by frequency and timing variables. Each of these clusters represents a song-type that is sung by multiple males, and the “typicality” of one individual’s version of this song-type is measured by how close that version lies to the center of the cluster. Thus, typicality measures how well a male has copied the average features of a song-type in his native population. We measured vocal learning ability more directly in song sparrows by hand-rearing birds and tutoring them with recorded song sparrow songs. Hand-reared birds learn from model songs mainly during a critical learning period 20 to 60 days post-hatching. Once our subjects began singing adult songs at about 9 months post-hatching, we assessed vocal learning success form the proportion of notes that were copied from model songs and the mean accuracy of those copies.

 

We also assessed all our subjects on five cognitive tests unrelated to vocal abilities. These non-vocal tests were: 1) a novel foraging task, in which the subject learned a new skill, removing a plastic lid from a well, to obtain a food reward; 2) a color association, in which the subject learned that one color of lid concealed food while another color did not; 3) a color reversal, in which the previously-rewarded color became the unrewarded one and vice versa; 4) a spatial learning task, in which the subject learned that a food reward could be found at one particular spatial position within its cage; and 5) a detour-reaching task, in which the subject learned to detour to the open end of a clear plastic cylinder to obtain food, rather than pecking directly at it through the cylinder walls. Performance on all five tasks improved gradually over trials in both species of subjects, and we used the number of trials needed to reach a specified performance criterion as our measure of individual cognitive performance for each task.

 

We found that different measures of cognitive performance are not consistently correlated with each other in either swamp sparrows or song sparrows. The one exception to this rule is the relationship between color association and color reversal: individuals that performed well on one of these tasks also performed well on the other in both study species. These two tasks are the most similar out of the entire battery of tests in terms of what subjects are asked to do, so perhaps it is not surprising that performance on these two tests is positively associated. Other than this exception, our measures of non-vocal learning ability were not correlated with each other. In addition, our measures of vocal learning ability did not show consistent positive correlations with any of the measures of non-vocal cognitive performance. In humans, another test for a general intelligence factor is whether scores on all cognitive tests load positively on a particular type of multivariate measure (called a principal component); the song sparrow and swamp sparrow results also fail this test. We conclude that there is no evidence of a general intelligence factor in these sparrows, and that song does not provide information about cognitive ability in either species.
